poems.japaneseText: Netari okitari ochiba suru

poems.englishText: Wide awake and feeling the moon right above
poems.japaneseText: Hokkari samete maue no tsuki o kanjiteiru

poems.englishText: Withering grass I sit on its beauty
poems.japaneseText: Kareyuku kusa no utsukushisa ni suwaru

poems.englishText: I live withdrawn and a wren
poems.japaneseText: Hissori kuraseba misosazai

poems.englishText: Dangling the snow falling on a bagworm
poems.japaneseText: Burari to sagatte yuki furu minomushi

poems.englishText: Just as they are weeds sprout
poems.japaneseText: Aru ga mama zassou to shite me o fuku

poems.englishText: From the mountain white flowers to my desk
poems.japaneseText: Yama kara shiroi hana o tsukue ni

poems.englishText: Into the sky young bamboo with no troubling thoughts
poems.japaneseText: Sora e wakatake no nayami mo nashi

poems.englishText: Around me all grasses every one blooming
poems.japaneseText: Mi no mawari kusa darake minna saiteru

poems.englishText: I roll on my back and there's the blue sky
poems.japaneseText: Korori nekorobeba aozora

poems.englishText: Seeking what I go through the wind
poems.japaneseText: Nani o motomeru kaze no naka yuku

poems.englishText: In the depths of the green leaves the path still then a grave
poems.japaneseText: Aoba no oku e nao michi ga atte haka

poems.englishText: The moon before you know it brightens and katydids
poems.japaneseText: Tsuki ga itsushika akarukunareba kirigirisu

poems.englishText: Butterflies entangling in the shadow in the sun
poems.japaneseText: Tefutefu motsuretsutsu kagehinata

poems.englishText: Once you die, weeds rain falls
poems.japaneseText: Shindeshimaeba, zassou ame furu

poems.englishText: Before death a cool breeze
poems.japaneseText: Shi o mae ni suzushii kaze

poems.englishText: Even while wind chimes tinkle death sneaks up
poems.japaneseText: Fuurin no naru sae shi no shinobiyoru

poems.englishText: Have no thoughts to leave the evening's sweet potato leaves aflutter
poems.japaneseText: Omoi oku koto wa nai yuube no imo no ha hirahira

poems.englishText: The wound healing turning autumnal the wind blows
poems.japaneseText: Kizu ga ieyuku aki meita kaze to natte kaze fuku

poems.englishText: I walk and cuckoos I hurry and cuckoos
poems.japaneseText: Arukeba kakkou isogeba kakkuu

poems.englishText: Heart empty the rough waves rolling in rolling out
poems.japaneseText: Kokoro munashiku aranami no yosete wa kaeshi

poems.englishText: Crouched on a dune today I still can't see Sado
poems.japaneseText: Sakyuu ni uzukumari kyou mo Sado wa mienai

poems.englishText: Legs stretched toward the rough sea before and after the journey
poems.japaneseText: Araumi e ashi nagedashite tabi no atosaki

poems.englishText: Having come this far I drink water and leave
poems.japaneseText: Koko made o koshi mizu nonde saru

poems.englishText: A butterfly aflutter has gone over the roof tiles
poems.japaneseText: Tefutefu hirahira iraka o koeta

poems.englishText: Sobering a wind sadly blows through me
poems.japaneseText: Yoizame no kaze no kanashiku fukinukeru

poems.englishText: My heart calms down and the sound of the water
poems.japaneseText: Kokoro ochitsukeba mizu no oto

poems.englishText: I follow the bright and dark sides of a wind
poems.japaneseText: Kaze no meian o tadoru

poems.englishText: From the moon flutters down a persimmon leaf
poems.japaneseText: Tsuki kara hirari to kaki no ha

poems.englishText: Waiting for what day by day dead leaves grow deep
poems.japaneseText: Nani o matsu hi ni hi ni ochiba fukounaru

poems.englishText: Drying up the water's clarity
poems.japaneseText: Karetekuru mizu no sumi yo

poems.englishText: Wash 'em and daikon grow even more white
poems.japaneseText: Araeba daikon iyoiyo shiroshi

poems.englishText: With a shadow too desultorily late night I'm eating
poems.japaneseText: Kage mo bosoboso yofuke no watashi ga tabeteiru

poems.englishText: I know the footfalls stepping on the fallen leaves coming closer
poems.japaneseText: Ochiba fumikuru sono ashioto wa shitteiru

poems.englishText: After all being alone's lonesome the withered grass
poems.japaneseText: Yappari hitori wa samishii karekusa

poems.englishText: Leaves fallen all the more intimate my neighbor's light
poems.japaneseText: Ochiba shite sarani shitashiku otonari no hi no

poems.englishText: Out of the wind caw caw crows
poems.japaneseText: Kaze no naka kara kaakaa karasu

poems.englishText: The leaves fallen no more leaves to fall the sun
poems.japaneseText: Ha no ochite ochiru ha wa nai taiyou

poems.englishText: Snow falls I have things to eat snow falls
poems.japaneseText: Yuki furu taberu mono wa atte yuki furu

poems.englishText: Moon's brightness I wonder where they're bombing
poems.japaneseText: Tsuki no akarusa wa doko o bakugeki shiteiru koto ka

poems.englishText: Snow falling on snow battle is about to begin they say
poems.japaneseText: Yuki e yuki furu tatakai wa kore kara da to iu

poems.englishText: The town's festive you've returned as bones have you
poems.japaneseText: Machi wa omatsuri o-hone to natte kaeraretaka

poems.englishText: Horse too requisitioned grandpa grandma
poems.japaneseText: Uma mo mesarete ojiisan obasan

poems.englishText: Legs and arms left in China you are back to Japan
poems.japaneseText: Ashi wa te wa Shina ni nokoshite futatabi Nihon ni

poems.englishText: Wordlessly playing a single bird in the blossoms
poems.japaneseText: Damatte asubu tori no ichiwa ga hana no naka

poems.englishText: The spring wind's bagworm has taken a sudden peek
poems.japaneseText: Harukaze no minomushi hyoito nozoita

poems.englishText: Taking a sudden peek the bagworm doesn't cry
poems.japaneseText: Hyoito nozoite minomushi wa nakanai

poems.englishText: The green of the grass I return barefoot
poems.japaneseText: Kusa no aosa yo hadashi de modoru

poems.englishText: In rows bamboo shoots turning into bamboo
poems.japaneseText: Narande takenoko take ni naritsutsu

poems.englishText: In the wind I walk blaming myself
poems.japaneseText: Kaze no naka onore o semetsutsu aruku

poems.englishText: Winter shower all the rice I got cooked good
poems.japaneseText: Shigururu ya aru dake no gohan yo taketa

poems.englishText: Death held tight the cayenne pepper scarlet
poems.japaneseText: Shi o hishi to tougarashi makka na

poems.englishText: Death's stillness is the clear sky a leafless tree
poems.japaneseText: Shi no shizukesa wa harete ha no nai ki

poems.englishText: There in front of death I put the moon
poems.japaneseText: Soko ni tsuki o shi no mae ni oku

poems.englishText: I open the window the spring filling the window
poems.japaneseText: Mado akete mado ippai no haru

poems.englishText: Stillness, bamboo shoots have all turned into bamboo
poems.japaneseText: Shizukesa, takenoko minna take ni natta

poems.englishText: Living alone and green green is the grass
poems.japaneseText: Hitori sumeba aoao to shite kusa

poems.englishText: A hop a single red frog
poems.japaneseText: Tonde ippiki akagaeru

poems.englishText: Near my body water comes flowing
poems.japaneseText: Mi no chikaku mizu no nagarete kuru

poems.englishText: From somewhere clouds appear autumn clouds
poems.japaneseText: Doko kara tomo naku kumo ga detekite aki no kumo

poems.englishText: Autumn wind, whichever way I want to go as far as I can go
poems.japaneseText: Akikaze, ikitai hou e ikeru tokoro made

poems.englishText: Since I stopped coming across people the mountain butterflies
poems.japaneseText: Hito ni awanakunarite yori yama no tefutefu

poems.englishText: With this body that can die any place spring wind
poems.japaneseText: Doko demo shineru karada de shumpuu

poems.englishText: Balmy the butterfly is dead
poems.japaneseText: Uraura chou wa shindeiru

poems.englishText: Cherry blossoms at their peak a prison
poems.japaneseText: Sakura mankai ni shite keimusho

poems.englishText: Of the house where I was born no trace left fireflies
poems.japaneseText: Umareta ie wa atokata mo nai hotaru

poems.englishText: Water's delicious frog croak
poems.japaneseText: Mizu no umasa o kawazu naku

poems.englishText: Letting the moon as far as my bed I decide to sleep
poems.japaneseText: Nedoko made tsuki o ire neru koto ni suru

poems.englishText: The darkness of the rice trusty I wash it
poems.japaneseText: Kome no kurosa mo tanomoshiku arau

poems.englishText: My bellybutton a pool of sweat
poems.japaneseText: Heso ga ase tameteiru

poems.englishText: Walls crumbling from there vine grass
poems.japaneseText: Kabe ga kuzurete soko kara tsurugusa

poems.englishText: That's a pre-death butterfly dance
poems.japaneseText: Sore wa shi no mae no tefutefu no mai

poems.englishText: Autumn's end-turned-fly crawls about
poems.japaneseText: Aki mo owari no hae to nari haiaruku

poems.englishText: Moon invisible moonlit water brimming
poems.japaneseText: Tsuki wa mienai tsukiakari no mizu manman

poems.englishText: Cawing a crow, flapping a crow, with no place to settle down
poems.japaneseText: Naite karasu no, tonde karasu no, ochitsuku tokoro ga nai

poems.englishText: The sound of water today too alone I travel
poems.japaneseText: Mizuoto kyou mo hitori tabi yuku

poems.englishText: Mountain's quietness the white flower
poems.japaneseText: Yama no shizukesa wa shiroi hana

poems.englishText: Can't calm down the futon heavy I sleep
poems.japaneseText: Ochitsukenai futon omotaku neru

poems.englishText: Under burning heaven the railway track straight
poems.japaneseText: Enten no reeru massugu

poems.englishText: A crow flies away I'll cross the water
poems.japaneseText: Karasu tondeyuku mizu o wataro

poems.englishText:
where the walls are
falling apart the
vines the grass

men women
and the shadows too
dancing

the waves sound sometimes
close and sometimes far away
how much more of life

Pine trees
With branches all drooping—
Namu-kanzeon sutra.
poems.japaneseText: Matsu wa mina / eda tarete / namu-kanzeon
Matsukaze ni / ake kure no / kane tsuite

poems.englishText:
Sweeping the yard for a change,
Flowers in the hedge are in bloom.
poems.japaneseText: Hisashiburini haku / kakine no hana ga saita

poems.englishText:
Getting further and further
Into the mountains,
But still deep blue mountains.
poems.japaneseText: Wakeittemo / wakeittemo / aoi yama

poems.englishText:
Soaked and Soggy to the core,
It's a milestone.
poems.japaneseText: Shitodo ni nurete / korewa michishirube no ishi

poems.englishText:
Under the canopy of scorching heaven
I walk and beg.
poems.japaneseText: Enten wo itadaite / koi aruku

poems.englishText:
Lone crow is cawing;
I'm alone too.
poems.japaneseText: Karasu naite / watashi mo hitori

poems.englishText:
In the midst of life and death
Snow's falling thick and fast.
poems.japaneseText: Shoji no naka no / yuki furishikiru

poems.englishText:
Leaves are falling;
I walk and walk.
poems.japaneseText: Konoha chiru / aruki tsumeru

poems.englishText:
All alone,
Letting mosquitoes bite my flesh.
poems.japaneseText: Hitoride / ka ni kuwareteiru

poems.englishText:
Stretching my legs
To the light of a westering sun.
poems.japaneseText: Nagedashite / mada hi no aru ashi

poems.englishText:
Walking with a dragonfly
Resting on my sedge-hat.
poems.japaneseText: Kasa ni tombo wo / tomarasete / aruku

poems.englishText:
It's a straight road
That makes me feel lonely.
It's a lonely road that has no turning.

In silence
I put on straw sandals for today.
poems.japaneseText: Damatte / kyo no waraji haku

poems.englishText:
Late autumn rain's falling;
I have yet to die.
poems.japaneseText: Shigururu ya / shinanai de iru

poems.englishText:
My shadow on the water,
Traveler I am.
poems.japaneseText: Mizu ni kage aru / tabibito de aru

poems.englishText:
Late autumn rain's falling
Into the mountain,
Towards which I go on walking.
poems.japaneseText: Shigururu ya / shigururu yama e / ayumi iru

poems.englishText:
Buds of trees,
Buds of grasses,
I keep on walking.
poems.japaneseText: Kinome  / kusanome / aruki tsuzukeru

poems.englishText:
I've survived—
Scratching my body.
poems.japaneseText: Iki nokotta karada / kaite iru

poems.englishText:
Mountains I've left for good
Are going out of sight.
poems.japaneseText: Mata miru koto mo nai yama ga / toozakaru

poems.englishText:
Crickets are chirping,
Chirping to me all the time.
poems.japaneseText: Koorogi ni / nakarete bakari

poems.englishText:
Shrike is chirping;
No place to throw away myself.
poems.japaneseText: Mozu maite / mi no sutedokoro nashi

poems.englishText:
Slipped, tumbled,
Mountain is quiet and alone.
poems.japaneseText: Subette koronde / yama ga hissori

poems.englishText:
My tired legs—
Dragonfly landed on one.
poems.japaneseText: Tsukareta ashi e / tombo tomatta

poems.englishText:
Monk-robe
Threadbare so—
Grass seeds.
poems.japaneseText: Houe / konnani yaburete / kusa no mi
Yuwa kage / masashiku / mizu ga waite iru

poems.englishText:
Those clouds threw a rain shower;
I'm wet through.
poems.japaneseText: Ano kumo ga / otoshita ane ni / nurete iru

poems.englishText:
Autumn is come;
Sitting on the weeds.
poems.japaneseText: Aki to natta / zasso ni suwaru

poems.englishText:
Water so tasty,
Flowing all over.
poems.japaneseText: Konnani umai mizu ga / afurete iru

poems.englishText:
Have come down to the village
With the sound of water.
poems.japaneseText: Mizuoto to isshoni / sato e orite kita

poems.englishText:
No clouds whatsoe'er,
I took off my sedge-hat.
poems.japaneseText: Mattaku kumo ga nai / kasa wo nugi

poems.englishText:
Drunk,
Found myself sleeping with crickets.
poems.japaneseText: Youte / koorogi to / nete itayo

poems.englishText:
Sound of raindrops,
You're getting old, too.
poems.japaneseText: Amadare no oto mo / toshi totta

poems.englishText:
No more doors to beg,
Clouds o'er the mountains.
poems.japaneseText: Mono gou ie mo nakunari / yama niwa kumo

poems.englishText:
—Reminiscence—
My sedge-hat
Getting leaky at last.
poems.japaneseText: Kasa mo / moridashita ka

poems.englishText:
—Self-ridicule—
I'm leaving
With my backside wet
In late autumn rain.
poems.notes:
Note: Another self of Santoka's is watching himself from behind with
self-scorn. He is dual-eyed, before and hind, like a frog
or a dragonfly.
poems.japaneseText: Ushiro sugata no / shigurete yuku ka

poems.englishText:
Into begging bowl of iron
Down came the hailstones.
poems.japaneseText: Teppachu no naka e mo arare

poems.englishText:
My native town
Far, far away—
Burgeoning trees.
poems.japaneseText: Furusato wa / tooku shite / ki no me

poems.englishText:
Getting out of a nice bath
Into lovely moonlight.
poems.japaneseText: Yoi yu kara / yoi tsuki e deta

poems.englishText:
Among budding trees
Birds are now singing.
poems.japaneseText: Haya mebuku ki de / naite iru

poems.englishText:
Something fell on my sedge-hat—
Camellia.
poems.japaneseText: Kasa e pottori / tsubaki datta
Itadaite / tarite hitori no / hashi wo oku

poems.englishText:
In autumn wind
I pick up a pebble.
poems.japaneseText: Akikaze no / ishi wo hirou

poems.englishText:
Alongside today's road
Dandelions in bloom.
poems.japaneseText: Kyo nomichi no / tampopo saita

poems.englishText:
It's raining in my hometown;
I'm walking barefoot.
poems.japaneseText: Ame furu furusato wa / hadashi de aruku

poems.englishText:
Having moved in and settled down,
I'm surrounded by flowers of the opposite shore/
flowers of the autumnal equinox.*
poems.japaneseText: Utsuri kite / o-higanbana no / hana zakari
poems.notes:
*opposite shore (Higan)—Buddhistic term.
autumnal equinox (Higan/Shuubun-no-hi)—day on the calendar.

poems.japaneseText: Asayake / ame furu / daikon makou

poems.englishText:
Out of the evening sky
I pick and pluck a yuzu-citrus.*
poems.notes:
*Yuzu—yellow, sour and fragrant citrus resembling a lemon, not oval
but round and softer. It is symbolic of Japan's winter.
Yuzu-trees, together with persimmon-trees, are seen in the yards of
rural houses—typical scenery of Japan's countryside just as the
apple tree is to the West. On the day of winter solstice, it is the
custom with the Japanese to enjoy yuzu-bath (Yuzu-yu) either in the
household or in public bathhouses (Sentoh). Urban dwellers can get
yuzu at stores. Yuzu is also used as healthy natural vinegar. A
good subject (season-word) for Haiku. Lots of Haikuists like to
compose yuzu-ku around this season. (T. Nonin)
poems.japaneseText: Yuuzora kara / yuzu no hitotsu wo morau

poems.englishText:
Tea-blossoms keep falling—
Let them fall as they do.
poems.japaneseText: Cha-no-hana no / chiru bakari / chirashite oku
Fuyu ga kiteiru / kigire / takegire

poems.englishText:
The moon has risen;
I'm awaiting nobody and nothing.
poems.japaneseText: Tsuki ga nobotte / nani wo matsu deno naku

poems.englishText:
There's something to eat,
This and that—
Windy all day.
poems.japaneseText: Are kore / taberumo wa atte / kaze no ichinichi

poems.englishText:
Sound of water—
I'm truly settled down and relaxed.
poems.japaneseText: Mizuoto / shinjitsu / ochitsuki mashita

poems.englishText:
Falling leaves—
Far beyond,
I see Buddha.
poems.japaneseText: Ochiba furu oku fukaku / mi-hotoke wo miru
Gochu yuki furu / hitori to shite / hi wo taku

poems.englishText:
Warm day,
I have something more to eat.
poems.japaneseText: Nukui hi no / mada taberumono wa aru

poems.englishText:
Snow's falling on snow,
I'm in quietude.
poems.japaneseText: Yuki e yuki furu / shizukesa ni oru
tsukiyo / temiyage wa / kome datta-ka

poems.englishText:
Camellias are in bloom;
There are tombstones.
poems.japaneseText: Tsubaki hiraite / haka ga aru

poems.englishText:
A tiny vase,
A twig of camellia in it.
poems.japaneseText: Ichirin-zashi no / tsubaki ichirin

poems.englishText:
What's that sound—
Must be a bird
Eating berries since morning.
poems.japaneseText: Oto wa / asa kara kinomi wo tabe ni kita tori ka
Nuitemo / nuitemo / kusa no shuuchaku wo nuku

poems.englishText:
Today I picked butterburrs,
Ate butterburrs.
poems.japaneseText: Kyo wa / fuki wo tsumi / fuki wo tabe

poems.englishText:
Sparrows dance,
Dandelions fall.
poems.japaneseText: Suzume odoru ya / tanpopo chiru ya

poems.englishText:
Morn is about to dawn,
Windows just opened—
Fresh young leaves.
poems.japaneseText: Mou ake souna / mado akete / aoba

poems.englishText:
Long hair...
Gray.
poems.japaneseText: Nagai ke ga / shiraga

poems.englishText:
I'm true and obedient to my mind;
Rice has just been cooked well.
poems.japaneseText: kokoro sunaoni / gohan ga fuita

poems.englishText:
It's good after all
To be all by myself—
Weeds.
poems.japaneseText: Yappari / hitori ga yoroshii / zasso

poems.englishText:
Whole day long
No one has come today—
Firelies.
poems.japaneseText: Kyo mo ichinichi / dare mo konakatta / houtaru

poems.englishText:
Stark naked I am,
Dragonfly trying to land on me.
poems.japaneseText: Suppadaka e / tombo tomarou to suru ka

poems.englishText:
Making a rustling sound,
Mute insect has come.
poems.japaneseText: Kasari kosori / oto sasete / nakanu mushi ga kita
matsukaze suzushiku / hito mo tabe / uma mo tabe

poems.englishText:
All day long, today
I have walked in the wind.
poems.japaneseText: Kyo mo ichinichi / Kaze wo aruite kita

poems.englishText:
What's this? What's that?
Everything is blooming.
poems.japaneseText: Nani ga nani yara / minna saite iru

poems.englishText:
When I walk, I see buttercups;
When I sit, I see buttercups.
poems.japaneseText: Arukeba kinpohge / suwareba kinpohge

poems.englishText:
Thistles—
Bright in the morning
After the rain.
poems.japaneseText: Azami azayakana / asa no ame agari

poems.englishText:
Hanging down my head,
I see nothing but pebbles.
poems.japaneseText: Utsumuite / ishikoro bakari

poems.englishText:
Drippings from young leaves,
Drippings from my bamboo-hat.
poems.japaneseText: Wakaba no shizuku de / kasa no shizuku de

poems.englishText:
Come on, fireflies, come on;
I've come to my native town.
poems.japaneseText: Houtaru koi koi / furusato ni kita

poems.englishText:
Bamboo sprouts of the temple
Have grown into bamboos.
poems.japaneseText: Otera no takenoko / take ni natta
Matsukaze matsukage / nekoronde

poems.englishText:
Day is breaking;
I whet a sickle.
poems.japaneseText: Akete kuru / kama wo togu

poems.englishText:
I'm listening alone—
Woodpecker.
poems.japaneseText: Hitori kiite ite / kitsutsuki

poems.englishText:
The spa—
Gushing out and overflowing:
I immerse my body in it.
poems.japaneseText: Waite afureru nakani / neteiru

poems.englishText:
I'm waiting;
Cherries are ripe.
poems.japaneseText: Matte iru / sakuranbo urete iru

poems.englishText:
Nestling down in the mountain (spa),
I doff my clothes.
poems.japaneseText: Yama futokoro no / hadaka to nari

poems.englishText:
A whole day in the mountains;
Ants are walking, too.
poems.japaneseText: Yama no ichinichi / ari mo aruite iru

poems.englishText:
Clouds are sailing fast
To make the moon look better.
poems.japaneseText: Kumo ga isoide / yoi tsuki ni suru

poems.englishText:
I'm always alone,
Red dragonfly.
poems.japaneseText: Itsumo hitori de / akatombo
Tabi no houe ga / kawaku made / zasso no kaze

poems.englishText:
It wiggles;
A bagworm.
poems.japaneseText: Ugoite / minomushi datta yo

poems.englishText:
Across the water
Lights of the brothels
Began to twinkle.
poems.japaneseText: Mizu wo hedatete / onagoya no hi ga / matataki dashita

poems.englishText:
The mountains
Hazed and overlapped—
My home town.
poems.japaneseText: Kasunde Kasanatte / yama ga furusato

poems.englishText:
In the spring breeze
One begging-bowl is there.
poems.japaneseText: Harukaze no / hachinoko hitotsu

poems.englishText:
—Returning to my hermitage—
I'm home after a long absence;
Bamboo sprouts are shooting forth
Everywhere.
poems.japaneseText: Hisabisa modoreba / takenoko nyoki nyoki

poems.englishText:
Soaked with rain and sweat,
Plough-horse gets many a scolding.
poems.japaneseText: Bisshori nurete / shiro kaku uma wa / shikararete bakari

poems.englishText:
Rain and shine—
The fields have turned
Into green paddies.
poems.japaneseText: Haretari futtari / aota ni natta

poems.englishText:
A thicket—
That's the place
Corpses are cremated.
poems.japaneseText: kusa shigeru / soko wa shinin wo / yaku tokoro

poems.englishText:
Wet with morning dew,
I take a wayward course.
poems.japaneseText: Asatsuyu shittori / Ikitai hou e iku

poems.englishText:
Little cuckoos—
I will go beyond
That mountain morrow.
poems.japaneseText: Hototogisu / asu wa ano yama / koete ikou

poems.englishText:
Doffing my bamboo-hat,
I'm thoroughly wet.
poems.japaneseText: Kasa wo nugi / shimizimi to nure

poems.englishText:
cockroach!
your whiskers are long
and so are mine
poems.japaneseText: Aburamushi / omae no hige mo / nobite iru

poems.englishText:
This
journey
without
goal
weeping
locust.

Between life
death / snow
still falling.

Road
no end
loneliness.

On my straw
hat
dragonfly clings
keep walking.

In this
blizzard
try to
sleep,
not die.

Rain
falling on
home
country
walk barefoot / here.

Push
apart
step
thru
push
apart
step
thru
blue-green
mountain.
poems.notes: The difficulty in finding an English equivalent to Santoka

poems.englishText:
These
my hands
these
my feet
warm inside

All night
long
dogs bark,
I walk.

Unpleasant days:
days I don't walk, days without booze,
haikuless days.

Sake for flesh, haiku for soul:
sake is the haiku of the flesh
haiku is the sake of the soul.

Walking on and on -
my only course.

So this is what
he calls his "tea grove" -
one miserable bush!

No water but that
trickling from
the farmer in the dry ricefield.

The thistles -
fresh and sparkling
after morning rain.

At the mountain-foot
many graves resting
in the warm sunlight.

This road straight -
and empty of company.

Going deeper
and still deeper
into green mountains.

The sunshine freshly
reflecting from
my freshly-shaven head.

Begging: I accept
the burning sun.

One pot is enough;
I wash the rice.

Shining brightly in the sunshine:
my little bowl of rice.

Within life and death
snow ceaselessly falls.

I have no home;
autumn gets bleaker.

Worn and torn daily
and falling in shreds:
my cloak for travelling.

The giant camphor-tree:
the dog and I
completely soaked.

Nice road
leading to a nice building:
a crematorium.

Rain in my eyes:
I can't read the signpost.

The sky at sunset -
a little alcohol would taste so good.

The long night:
made even longer
by a barking dog.

The louse I've caught
is warmer than I am!

Nonchalantly pissing
off the road
soaking the young weeds.

Winter rain clouds -
soldiers off to China
to be blown to bits.

Marching together
on the ground their feet
will never pound again.

Leaving hands and feet
behind in China:
Japanese soldiers come home.

Will the municipality
stage a banner day
for those brought back as bones?

Baggage I can't throw off
so heavy front and back.

In the calm stillness
after the rainstorm:
flies.

Slowly but surely
I adopt the vices
of my dead father.

Sweat:
collecting
in my navel.

Today's lunch:
just water.

Breaking the dead branches
thinking of nothing.

Today again
no letters.
Only butterflies.

At last!
The mail's arrived.
Soon ripe fruit will fall.

The leaves fall.
From now on
water will taste better and better.

A little woozy,
leaves fall one by one.

My begging-bowl
accepts the falling leaves.

Hailstones also
drop into my begging-bowl.

If I sell my rags
and buy some alcohol—
will there still be loneliness?

Twilight - the sound
of a sad letter
dropping into a postbox.

Goallessly
I walk amongst tombstones.

Slowly, slowly
falling apart:
my final autumn.

I've become a real beggar now:
one towel.

The few flies that remain
find me familiar.

Pissing blood -
how long will I be able
to carry on?

Coughing, coughing -
and nobody to slap my back.

No money, no possessions,
no teeth -
all alone.

My heart's exhausted -
the mountains, the sea
are too beautiful.

Mountains I'll never see again
fade in the distance.

When I die:
weeds,
falling rain.

Some life remains:
I scratch my belly...

poems.japaneseText:
Hitotsu areba
koto taru nabeno
kome o togu.
poems.englishText:
One washes rice
in a metal pot;
only one pot, that's enough
for me.
or
I wash rice
in a metal pot;
one pot's enough.
or
Washing rice
in a metal pot;
one pot's enough.
poems.notes: Colloquialisms mark his haiku. He used easy, plain language at its best, never the literary, poetic diction of more ordinary writers.

poems.japaneseText:
Korogi yo,
asu no kome dake wa
aru.
poems.englishText:
Oh cricket!
there is enough rice, at least
for tomorrow.

poems.notes: The following haiku in not grammatically correct Japanese. Santoka often was careless about grammar. He seemed to want us to read between the lines, and more often than not his grammatical mistakes, a sign of his nonchalance, add charm to his work.
poems.japaneseText:
Anta to ko-shite kisha ga
itta ri kitari suru
kemuri.
poems.englishText:
In your company
going this way and that...
the smoke of train.

poems.japaneseText:
Ame furu
furu-sato wa
hadashi de aruku.
poems.englishText:
The old home
in the rain...
I walk barefooted.

poems.japaneseText:
Teppatsu no
naka e mo
arare.
poems.englishText:
Into my begging bowl,
i too,
hailstones.

forsaken
still something
in these legs

it's
come
to these
tired legs
to stop this dragonsly

slipping and falling
mountain silence

getting just enough
to eat: rain
*by begging that is

no matter news is
good or bad—spring snow

taking it easy,
taking a piss-weeds
bud all over

no sake.
drink in the moon

certain days
stop begging to take in
the mountains
poems.notes: Moreover, as Scott himself says of an old Frank Zappa lyric “you gotta get into it before you get out of it; you gotta get out of it before you get into it.” I can tell you, not only does he apply this to his translations, but Scott commands readers to thoroughly get in and out of Santoka's haiku—his English versions rendered as if they themselves, were... Japanese.

poems.englishText:
rock
shadow
water
gushing
sure
as
I live
Milky Way middle night drunkard dancing

this
robe
this
worn
this
weedy
fruition
autumn-sitting in weeds

peckers
and
pussies
a hot
bath
over-flowing
still alive a body for a body to scratch

naked
conversation
abounds

jazz noise won't
get you there
a sutra will

straight ahead
out-reaching loneliness
road.

if we walk: the cuckoo.
if we hurry: the cuckoo.

walking:
buttercups
sitting:
buttercups

traveling
endlessly
clipping my nails

grilling a fish
even singeing a hand —
single life

a weed. a-
lone.
all right.

wind blows its way to
sea. deep in night.
alone

jazz noise won't
get you where
a sutra will
over morning noises a long bridge spans
all day today too no one came fireflies
until my clothes dry / this grassy breeze
spider spins its web I affirm my self
drizzling. / undying.
no matter news is / good or bad / spring snow
with the crowd around / a dead body / a sky without clouds
air raid sirens / one after another / persimmons are red
falling leaves / deep deep seeing / Buddha
as if someone is coming loquat leaf falling
wanting something to do grass blades stirring
in a cool / pine wind / people / eating / horses / eating
intimate / mountain / meadow / bush warbler / cries
tip tap comes a bug with no buzz
long away / come back: bamboo / shoots shooting
waiting / cherries / ripening
whatever it all is it all is blossoming
walking: grasses in seed. / sitting: grasses in seed.
there is only thisroad spring snow falling
after a rain a thistle clear morning
spring has come water sounds go where they do
neither waiting / nor not waiting / moonlight weeds
settled / down / persimmons / ripen / already
looking down all the small stones
spider makes its web I affirm my self
this day this far sandals come off
well now. / which way to go. / wind blowing.
nothing to wait on: / the risen moon
washed / the daikon absolutely white

poems.englishText:
The path
straight ahead
solitude

Silently
I put on today's
straw sandals

Today again
soaken wet
walking on a strange path

Today
I pick buttercups
I eat buttercups

No inn for the night
the moon
shows the way

Spring
I walk holding my begging bowl
up to where?

Light-hearted
I taste
water

My meal
today
water

In the water
my reflection
as a pilgrim

In my begging bowl
the glaring whiteness
of rice

On my own
attacked
by mosquitos

I slap flies
I slap mosquitos
I slap myself

With a dragonfly
on my bamboo hat
walking

On my tired feet
a dragonfly
has settled

From now on
I won't wear any watch
evening rain

Autumn rain
mountains more mountains
mountains I don't know

Just like this it rains
I am soaken wet
I walk

Soaken wet
the milestone
showing the way

I've just been given
something to eat
falling rain

This body
that has survived
I am scratching it

Far faraway
birds fly over
snowy mountains

My skull freshly shaved
really reflects
the sunlight

Now that I don't meet
anyone
mountain butterflies

In the mountain all day long
these ants too
walk

Some days sometimes
I don't beg
and gaze at the mountains

Getting further
from these mountains
I'll never see again

Not one cloud
I take off
my bamboo hat

This cloud there
let the rain down
that soaked me

Far
from my home village
budding trees

Someone speaks with a voice
like my father's
sad while travelling

At last some mail
from now on
ripe persimmons will fall

Postman
He brings me my mail
eats a persimmon
and then leaves

Everything may be happy
or sad
grass grows

Falling leaves
they also fall
in my begging bowl

Under the quilt
I sleep
dreaming of my home village

Now that no one comes anymore
chillis
have gone red

Picking up a flower
I don't know
I offer it to Buddha

Up to
the rows of graves
the waves break

Today
I am still alive
I stretch my legs

In public baths
Naked
the discussion gets
heated

Something's missing
a tooth fell out
I hurl it into the night

At the foot of the mountain
in the sun's heat
in line five or six graves

Heavy rain
the postman
comes from so far

This
my face
in the cold mirror?

Making fun of me
my figure seen from behind
going away
in the autumn rain?

poems.notes:
Comment by Addiss:
Here the calligraphy seems more restrained and graceful than the previous tanzaku, but the freedom of the brushwork is at least as strong as before, if more subtle. The single column of words is maintained within the center of the format as though the red paper were itself the blazing sunlight, withering the calligraphy as though it were Santoka's body in the heat.
For example, the kana syllable shi is created with a single thin verticle line in the center of the tanzaku, but when the character kaze is written three graphs later, it opens the space as it might cool the pores of a sweaty body.
For some viewers, it may seem odd to see a Santoka poem, with its simplicity of diction and plainness of speech, on a surface so highly decorated with fluid patterns of cut squares of gold leaf. However, the contrast may add to the effect of the calligraphy, just as it gives extra impact to the words of the haiku.

poems.englishText:
The road ahead
is lonesome

poems.japaneseText: あるけばかつこういそげばかつこう
poems.englishText:
walking,
downhill
running,
downhill

poems.japaneseText: この道しかない春の雪ふる
poems.englishText:
This is the only road
Snowfall in spring

poems.japaneseText: 笠にとんぼをとまらせてあるく
poems.englishText:
A dragonfly
on my straw hat,
I walk on

poems.japaneseText: ほうたるこいこいふるさとにきた
poems.englishText:
Firefly, come, come
We’ve made it to my hometown

poems.japaneseText: 雨ふるふるふるさとははだしであるく
poems.englishText:
rain falls and falls
walking barefoot
through my hometown

poems.japaneseText: ビルとビルとのすきまから見えて山の青さよ
poems.englishText:
In the cracks between the buildings
I can see the blue of the mountains

poems.japaneseText: ほととぎすあすはあの山こえて行かう
poems.englishText:
Cuckoo,
tomorrow let’s climb
over that mountain

poems.japaneseText: ふくろふはふくろふでわたしはわたしでねむれない
poems.englishText:
The owl, being an owl,
and I, being me,
can’t sleep

poems.japaneseText: どうしようもないわたしが歩いてゐる
poems.englishText:
Nothing else I can do
I’ll just keep on walking

poems.japaneseText: 月が昇れりわがまへの花ひらくべし
poems.englishText:
The moon rises
A flower blooming
Before my eyes

poems.japaneseText: もりもりもりあがる雲へ歩む
poems.englishText:
rising high high higher
walking toward the clouds

poems.japaneseText: つかれた脚へとんぼとまった
poems.englishText:
A dragonfly landed
at my weary feet

poems.japaneseText: 雨だれの音も年とった
poems.englishText:
Even the sound
of the rain
has grown old

poems.japaneseText: 何を求める風の中ゆく
poems.englishText:
Whatever you wish for
blows away in the wind

poems.japaneseText: 窓あけて窓いっぱいの春
poems.englishText:
Open the window
and the window
is filled with Spring

poems.japaneseText: 生死の中の雪ふりしきる
poems.englishText:
Snow falls endlessly
between life and death

poems.japaneseText: 歩きつづける彼岸花咲きつづける
poems.englishText:
I keep on walking
and the red spider lily
keeps on blooming

No path but this one—
I walk alone.

Walking into the wind,
heaping abuse upon myself.

Stretching out my feet;
Some daylight still remains.

A steady autumn drizzle,
one road, straight ahead.

At the tobacco shop
no cigarettes,
a cold rain falls.

The deep, cool moon
Appears between the buildings.

Going deeper,
And still deeper—
The green mountains.

I push my way through,
push my way through,
green mountains

Thinking of nothing,
I walk among
A forest of withered trees.
soppy with morning dew / I go off / in any direction I please
drizzly rain / only one road / to go by
husband and wife quarreling / night / spiders dangle down
as muddy water flows / it becomes clear
hurry down the road / never look back
no help / for the likes of me / I go on walking
get drunk / you hear all sorts of voices / winter rain
Heaven / doesn't kill me / it makes me write poems
even in / my iron begging bowl / hailstones
autumn wind / for all my walking / for all my walking
stretching out my feet / they touch the man from Shikoku
tree fallen over / sitting on it
on the road / a tooth / about to come loose
cold clouds / hurrying
not a cloud in sight / off comes my hat
camellia / I turned to look back at / red
nearly run over / by a car / cold cold road
the deeper I go / the deeper I go / green mountains

even in
my iron begging bowl
hailstones

a drink would be nice now
sunset sky

all day
in the mountains
ants too are walking

autumn wind
for all my walking—-
for all my walking—-

poems.japaneseText: hana ga ha ni naru tôkyô yo sayônara
poems.englishText: the blossoms / have become leaves so / tokyo, i leave

poems.japaneseText: hana ga ha ni naru tôkyô yo sayônara
poems.englishText: hey, tokyo / your blossoms are leaves: / good-bye!

poems.japaneseText: itsu to naku sakura ga saite atte wa wakareru
poems.englishText: well, the cherries / they blossomed in a wink / we meet, we part

poems.japaneseText: itsu to naku sakura ga saite atte wa wakareru
poems.englishText: i almost missed / the cherry's bloom: soon as / we meet we part

poems.japaneseText: damatte kyô no waraji haku
poems.englishText: wordless / i put on my waraji / for today

poems.japaneseText: damatte kyô no waraji haku
poems.englishText: lips clenched / i put on today's footwear
New Year's Eve / is dumb and New Year's / even dumber
poems.japaneseText: ômisoka oroka nari ganjitsu nao oraoka nari
asu wa ganjitsu no tsume demo kirô
poems.englishText: this morning / i guess i'll clip the nails / of the new year

poems.japaneseText: asu wa ganjitsu no tsume demo kirô
poems.englishText: i guess i'll clip / my new year nails / this morning

publications.name: My Santoka Translations
publications.description:
Jesse Glass
My Santoka Translations
http://www.sendecki.com/ahadada/archives/2005/03/06/my_santoka_translations.php
        These are a few of my translations of the experimental, free-form haiku of Santoka (1882–1940). Santoka practiced “Walking Zen” and traveled Kyushu, Honshu, and Shikoku on foot as an itinerant monk begging enough money for a cup of sake and a bowl of rice a day. Santoka’s father was a womanizer and a spend-thrift and his mother killed herself on account of this. His memory of her body being pulled from the well in which she drowned herself haunted him all of his life.

publications.name: Weeds We'd Wed and A Life to Live
publications.description:
Book review by Jane Reichhold
LYNX, A Journal for Linking Poets, XXI:1 February, 2006
In 2000 and 2004, Scott Watson had two articles on his translations of Santoka published in the Tohoku Gakuin Review under the titles "Weeds We'd Wed" and "A Life to Live." What the readers will find in this book, are these two journal pieces, without revision or changes, along with the introductions. The cover of the book has an ink wash calligraphy and illustration by Ed Baker.
The first article "Weeds We'd Wed," begins with the story of how Scott Watson discovered the work of Taneda Santoka, both in English and then through Japanese friends in a poetry seminar. The translation by Cid Corman which as Watson notes, "is more Corman than Santoka" left him searching for versions that better compared to his own. Those of John Stevens's work came under his scrutiny, as well as the work published online by several sites and translators (not named, but should have mentioned Hiroaki Sato). Watson's own versions of the translations then appeared in the now discontinued US haiku magazine Persimmons.
The article continues with a brief biography of Santoka's life taken from the Kodansha Encyclopedia of Japan. What the encyclopedia avoids saying is that Santoka was an alcoholic who then drifted from job down to lower job, was divorced, and ended up traveling around as a mendicant Zen priest, begging from friends and writing travel diaries.
Watson then uses a page to describe and analyze Santoka's poetry and ends with his relationship to Zen poetry. Watson uses a Zen approach to translating the poems into a non form - giving them the number of words or lines as the spirit moves him. Thus, he ends up with such haiku:

publications.name: Long Dream: Santoka
publications.description:
Alex Fyffe
http://longdream.wordpress.com/category/poetry/taneda-santoka/
Taneda Santōka (1882-1940) was an early free-form haiku poet, a contemporary of Ogiwara Seisensui and Ozaki Hōsai. His given name was Taneda Shōichi (種田正一), but like most (if not all) Japanese haiku poets (俳人, haijin) he gave himself a haiku pseudonym (俳号, haigou). Santōka (山頭火) means “fire on the mountain.” I hope that you have enjoyed taking this little walk with me and Santōka. But now I think it’s time to let him walk the mountains alone, once again, with the insects. All poems taken from the Gendai Haiku Association Database (現代俳句協会, Modern Haiku Association)
